course.subject: COMP
course.name: C Programming Bridging Course
course.description: This course introduces the C programming language. It is intended for students who already have some experience in computer programming but wish to learn how to apply those programming skills to the C language. The course covers basic programming topics, such as variables, control, loops, and functions, to more advanced topics. Students explore these by self-learning of course materials together with guided programming exercises. Students without the prerequisites but possess relevant programming knowledge may seek instructor's approval for enrolling in the course. Graded P or F.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P OR COMP 1022Q (prior to 2020-21) OR ISOM 3230 OR ISOM 3320
course.exclusions: COMP 2011, COMP 2012H

reviews.author: clscompany
reviews.title: The most "hea" and easiest 1 credit course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic C programming stuff.

If you have enrolled in COMP1021/1022P/1022Q before(which most of you did), you will not have any difficulties to understand the course materials. The concepts used in C/C++ programming are pretty much the same as python/java. You just need to learn the syntax used in C/C++ specifically.

Overall this is just an 1 credit bridging course. Only basic and fundamental concepts are introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The course materials are provided through the internet. You don’t need to attend any class.

This year almost no videos were provided. The course materials mainly consisted of plain text and pictures. Everything was well-organised and explained clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
In order to gain a pass, you need to fulfil both requirements listed below.
1. Obtain 60% or above in 4 assignments total mark
2. Obtain 40% or above in the final exam

Gaining full mark in all assignments shouldn’t be a problem. The final exam is very easy and not tricky at all.

It is impossible to fail the course unless you do it on purpose. Otherwise, you must be a legend.
reviews.comment_workload:
The course materials were updated once a week. Usually, It took me 4-5 hours to read through the materials, test the codes, finish the review questions and submit exercise. The workload was very light.

I revised the whole night before the final exam. Then I recognised that it was completely unnecessary since the exam was very straightforward...

reviews.comment_teaching:
There are no face-to-face lectures.

All I needed to do was to visit the course websites and read through all the content. The concepts are all well structured and clearly delivered, so you should find no problem understanding the course content.

There are also instructional step-by-step videos teaching you how to do the assignments, so if you're stuck with the assignments you can always have a look. But of course, it would be more rewarding if you do the assignments and think them over all by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pass or fail.

Need to get above 60% overall in the assignments (by finishing at least 3 out of 4 of them) and 40% in the final exam. These should be a piece of cake as soon as you pay attention to the deadlines and revise for the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload is the 4 assignments submitted weekly (for summer), so the workload is light for a 1-credit course. The assignments, however, are quite difficult at times. But since there are instructional videos, I had no difficulty finishing them at all.
